definition: Han Fei, also known as Han Feizi 韓非子|韩非子[Han2 Fei1 zi3] (c. 280-233 BC), Legalist philosopher of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Han, one of the Seven Hero States of the Warring States 戰國七雄|战国七雄/Korea from the fall of the Joseon dynasty in 1897/Korea, esp. South Korea 大韓民國|大韩民国/surname Han
abbr. for 非洲[Fei1 zhou1], Africa
to not be/not/wrong/incorrect/non-/un-/in-/to reproach or blame/(colloquial) to insist on/simply must
Han Feizi, book of Legalist Philosophy authored by Han Fei 韓非|韩非[Han2 Fei1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)

sentences.english: Hanfeizi has reflected Hanfei's political viewpoint in a concentrated way.
sentences.chinese: 《韩非子》集中反映了韩非的政治观点。

sentences.english: Hanfeizi has reflected Hanfei's political viewpoint in a concentrated way.
sentences.chinese: 《韩非子》集中反映了韩非的政治观点。

sentences.english: Recognizing Han Fei, in particular its law philosophy is a responsibility.
sentences.chinese: 认识韩非，尤其是其法哲学思想是一种责任。

sentences.english: Hanfeizi is one of the most important writings in warring states period.
sentences.chinese: 《韩非子》是我国战国末期的一部重要文献。

sentences.english: Han Fei inherited and developed the perspectives of reason and desire of Huan-Law Teachings.
sentences.chinese: 韩非继承和发展了黄老之学的理欲观。

sentences.english: Today my aunt took me to Happy Land.
sentences.chinese: 今天我的姑姑带我去韩非乐园。

sentences.english: Legalist Han Fei theory and from different angles.
sentences.chinese: 法家韩非从不同角度论和。

sentences.english: But I'm sure that Han Fei the design is presented.
sentences.chinese: 但可以肯定的是韩非的设计思想比较坚决。

sentences.english: Han Fei is the great master of legal thinking at the end of the Warring States period.
sentences.chinese: 韩非是战国末季法家思想的集大成者。

sentences.english: Legalism Han Fei is a master of the late Warring States Period were.
sentences.chinese: 韩非是战国末年法家思想的集大成者。

sentences.english: The second chapter "Han Feizi" cites the historical facts reflection the thought.
sentences.chinese: 第二章是《韩非子》称引故实反映的思想。

sentences.english: Han Fei-tzu sat in lotus position on the bare wooden floor beside his wife's sickbed.
sentences.chinese: 韩非子坐在她妻子的病床旁，光木地板上的莲座里。

sentences.english: The Comparison of Mind Theory from Shyun Tze and Han Fei …
sentences.chinese: 荀子论心和韩非子所蕴涵的心论之比较研究。

sentences.english: In Part One, Han Fei advocated that the principles of benefits be drive of ruling the country.
sentences.chinese: 第一部分，韩非提出用利益原则来作为治国的驱动力。

sentences.english: Han Fei and the rule of law is based on the reality that exists.
sentences.chinese: 韩非的法治主义的基础是对现实存在的相信。

sentences.english: Rebelliously, Han Fei-tzu gave her the most false answer to her question.
sentences.chinese: 韩非子难以控制的给了她最错误的答案。

definition: Li Si (c. 280-208 BC), Legalist philosopher, calligrapher and prime minister of Qin kingdom and Qin dynasty from 246 to 208 BC
Su Qin (340-284 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)

Wei Lao (c. 450 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), advisor to the first Qin emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2], possible author of the Wei Liaozi 尉繚子|尉缭子[Wei4 Liao2 zi5] text on military strategy
Zhang Yi (-309 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)

Lü Buwei (?291-235 BC), merchant and politician of the State of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], subsequent Qin Dynasty 秦代[Qin2 dai4] Chancellor, allegedly the father of Ying Zheng 嬴政[Ying2 Zheng4], who subsequently became the first emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2]

Shang Yang (c. 390-338 BC), legalist philosopher and statesman of the state of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], whose reforms paved the way for the eventual unification of the Chinese empire by the Qin dynasty 秦朝|秦朝[Qin2 chao2]
Han Feizi, book of Legalist Philosophy authored by Han Fei 韓非|韩非[Han2 Fei1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Zhao Gao (?-207 BC), one of the most vile, corrupt and powerful eunuchs in Chinese history, responsible for the fall of Qin Dynasty
Shen Buhai (385-337 BC), legalist political thinker
Qin general Meng Tian (-210 BC), involved in 215 BC in fighting the Northern Xiongnu 匈奴 and building the great wall
Prince Dan of Yan (-226 BC), commissioned the attempted assassination of King Ying Zheng of Qin 秦嬴政 (later the First Emperor 秦始皇) by Jing Ke 荆轲 in 227 BC
Zou Yan (305-240 BC), founder of the School of Yin-Yang of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Jing Ke (-227 BC), celebrated in verse and fiction as would-be assassin of King Ying Zheng of Qin 秦嬴政 (later the First Emperor 秦始皇)
Duke Xiao of Qin, 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], ruled 361-338 BC during the Warring States Period
the state of Qin, one of the seven states of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Grand Scribe, the title by which Sima Qian 司馬遷|司马迁[Si1 ma3 Qian1] refers to himself in Records of the Historian 史記|史记[Shi3 ji4]
